text: Germany competed at the 1896 Summer Olympics in Athens, Greece. The Germans were the third most successful nation in terms of both gold medals (6 plus 1 as part of a mixed team) and total medals (13). Gymnastics was the sport in which Germany excelled. The German team had 19 athletes. The Germans had 75 entries in 26 events (of which 48 entries were in the 8 gymnastics events), taking 13 medals. ==Medalists== German team at sailing {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:90%" |- !Medal !Name !Sport !Event !Date |- | | || Gymnastics | Men's horizontal bar | |- | | || Gymnastics | Men's parallel bars | |- | rowspan=2| | rowspan=2|, Alfred Flatow, Gustav Flatow, Georg Hilmar, Fritz Hofmann, Fritz Manteuffel, Karl Neukirch, Richard Röstel, Gustav Schuft, Carl Schuhmann, Hermann Weingärtner | rowspan=2|Gymnastics | Men's team parallel bars | |- | Men's team horizontal bar | |- | rowspan=2| | rowspan=2| | Gymnastics | Men's vault | |- | Wrestling | Men's Greco-Roman | |- | | || Athletics | Men's 100 m | |- | | || Cycling | Men's road race | |- | | || Gymnastics | Men's horizontal bar | |- | rowspan=2| | rowspan=2| | rowspan=2|Gymnastics | Men's pommel horse | |- | Men's rings | |- | | || Gymnastics | Men's rope climbing | |- | | || Gymnastics | Men's vault | |} ==Athletics== Hofmann's silver medal in the 100 metres was the only medal earned by the German athletes, though they finished 4th or 5th an additional 4 times. Alfred Flatow was entered in the 100 metres but did not start.Butler, Maynard. The Olympic Games. In Mallon & Widlund, pp. 37–41.Ekkehard zur Megede : The history of Olympic athletics. Volume 1: 1896-1936. The two entered the doubles tournament as a pair, winning the gold medal in that competition as part of a mixed team; that medal is not counted for Germany. {|class=wikitable style="font-size:90%" |- !rowspan="2"|Athlete !rowspan="2"|Event !First round !Quarterfinals !Semifinals !colspan="2"|Finals |- !style="line-height:1em"|Opposition Result !style="line-height:1em"|Opposition Result !style="line-height:1em"|Opposition Result !style="line-height:1em"|Opposition Result !Rank |- |Friedrich Traun |Singles |align="center"| L |align="center" colspan="3"|Did not advance |align="center"|8 |} {| class=wikitable ! Opponent nation || Wins || Losses || Percent |- align=center |align=left| || 0 || 1 || 0.000 |- |colspan=4 bgcolor=lightgray| |- ! Total || 0 || 1 || 0.000 |} ==Weightlifting== Schuhmann's lift was equal to that of the bronze medallist, but lifting form was used as a tie-breaker in the event. {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%" |- !Athlete !Event !Weight (kg) !Rank |- |Carl Schuhmann |Two hand lift |align="center"|90 |align="center"|4 |} ==Wrestling== Schuhmann first faced Launceston Elliot, the one-handed lift weightlifting champion, defeating him fairly easily. He received a bye in the semifinals, to face Georgios Tsitas in the final match. That contest took two days, after it had been postponed on account of darkness 40 minutes into the first day. Schuhmann quickly won on the second morning. {| class=wikitable style="font-size:90%" |- !rowspan=2|Athlete !rowspan=2|Event !Quarterfinals !Semifinals !colspan=2|Final |- !Opposition Result !Opposition Result !Opposition Result !Rank |- |Carl Schuhmann |Greco-Roman |align=center| W |align=center|Bye |align=center| W |align=center| |} {| class=wikitable !
